title: Disgusting
body: To be told today my partner had lukemia and needed a tablet from queens hospital pharmacy today urgently. It said on the slip 30 mins wait we waited over 2 hours I phoned them twice to be told it still not ready yet that they would phone when ready. My partner went back in there after 2.5 Hours of waiting to be told it’s closed. Absolutely disgusting service.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Ear wax removal
body:
In theory Dorking GPs don’t do this but my GP arranged this for me as it was a prerequisite for a hearing test.
Very grateful

title: Great doctors and a lovely surgery
body: I’ve been a patient at Glebe Street Surgery for 7 years and have always received a great service. When I had a recurring ones one of the doctors went out of their way to see me and regularly check up on me. And when I struggled during Lockdown my doctor was especially caring and supportive. Ta a small enough practice to feel personal and personable, but still efficient and professional.

title: Ezcema review
body:
Doctor listened to my concerns, was understanding and suggested products and a plan.

Only comment sound quality could be better, at times it was difficult to hear

title: Absolutely fantastic staff at the A&E
body: Took my son into A&E and very impressed by the attentive considerate staff.  Hospital is not a nice place to be but made soo much better when treated by such a great team of people.  This hospital would be hugely missed if ever it were to closed.

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Breast Care
body: I visited the Spire for a mammogram and Ultra sound scan as I required a second opinion on a Previous diagnosis with another local hospital that I believed was incorrect. I was seen withIn 48 hours for my appointment with the consultant. At the same appointment after my scans I was given the news that I had cancer. I cannot thank the consultant and the hospital enough for their quickness on biopsy results and expert knowledge and that sometimes a second opinion, if you are concerned is worth it. In my experience it’s saved my life as my next mammogram would not have been for another 2 years. The hospital for their investigative care is excellent.

title: Great help
body: I wish your workers had same mindset as public as i can see how it can make a world a better place with the level of understanding you get from these sessions and it really help to open yourself to things sometimes we forget. Thank you for all your help.

readBy.name: Midlands Partnership NHS Foundation Trust o

title: Good practice
body: From the moment you arrive the staff are friendly and extremely helpful, the centre is spotlessly clean. You are well looked after and don't feel as if you've been left alone as you can sometimes feel when a single room. Infection Control was good, Staff all  put Gloves and Aprons on before entering room and removed them before leaving with thing as they are at the moment it was very reassuring.

title: Exceptional Care
body:
I wasn’t supposed to birth in Manchester, but my baby arrived at 35 weeks when we were here visiting family. The birth was quick and fairly traumatic with time in HDU required.
I’ve been struck by the level of care and compassion from staff in triage, delivery, HDU, maternity ward 47 and neonatal outreach team. Whilst it was never the plan for me to be here in many ways I’m glad I am, due to the care received. I’d also like to make special reference to the student midwives where nothing has been too much trouble and those involved in my care have demonstrated such kindness and knowledge along with being professional. This is all despite the context and significant work demand on all the staff. I’ve learned so much in terms of caring for my baby whilst here.

The neonatal outreach service has also allowed my baby to get the extra care required, without being separated from me. I’ve welcomed the frank discussions, humour and planned care. They’ve been lovely.

title: Excellent Care and Support!!
body:
I travelled a long way for a brief routine procedure and, in spite of Covid19 concerns, the precautions appeared to be very effective. The environment appeared hygienically clean and well prepared. Everything went very well and the whole experience was made   comfortable due to the reassuring level of professional care and attention provided by the outstandingly friendly, courteous and empathetic nursing staff. Finally, the documented instant results removed any anxious waiting periods.
Thank you!!

n.b. Perhaps one comment - the advanced documentation provided appears to require a thorough checking and revising as  some of the information was out of date and appeared to have been randomly updated which could have led to a degree of confusion.

title: Blood Test Result
body: I requested a blood test to be done 4th June, pending from just before lockdown, I was given an appointment middle of June but the GP forgot to send the form. To get the next appointment was a challenge of 3 weeks, line collapsed, no one informed me I could do it online. It's been already 2 weeks or more my samples were taken and they don't have a result. GP told me yesterday if I could call in another week time, and he was the same one that forgot to send the form before, so basically I don't have a result and no guarantee if I will and when.

author: AJH39
title: They have always given me the belief that I can manage my addiction
body:
I have been a regular narcotic user for the past 10 years; having undertaken various attempts to battle, conquer and manage my addiction. I have a number of ongoing health conditions which include mental health issues such as Schizophrenia and Bipolar.  
My psychiatrist advised that I should engage and meet with the team at Fareham Inclusion Substance Misuse Service (the Avalon Centre).  
From my very first meeting with a Key Worker I have been supported, encouraged and given tools with which I have been finally able to tackle my addiction. The care and assistance given to me has always felt very personal at the same time as being of a highly professional level.  
I am now 3 months clean - without having used any substances.  
Whilst I am of the knowledge that it is myself who has made this happen by engaging and working with the Inclusion Service, I cannot overstate that the work and support the service has provided is without doubt a basis for the recovery journey I am now on.  
The service have always given me the belief that I can manage my addiction and shown me that I can make so much more of my life as well as providing invaluable tools, advice and support to enable this.  
Whilst I may be at the start of my new journey in life I know that the Inclusion Service will be my partner on that journey for a long time to come.  
If I had not been able to access such a service or persons I can guarantee you my life and its prospects would be taking a very different direction - I really cannot express enough to you the importance, quality and excellence of the service the hub provides and what a lifeline it is to so many service users - including thankfully myself.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Good To give
title: Volunteering to make a difference
body:
I have just signed up to be a mentor at CGL and can't wait to get started! I have been affected by substance misuse and lost loved ones as a result :(  
I had never heard of CGL before and have been looking at organisations that i could give my time to.  
Nicola the lady who interviewed me made me feel so at ease. I have no qualifications but bags of empathy and she has boosted my confidence by making me realise this is all that is needed. I cannot wait to get started and help those in need.  
The organisation seem so passionate about helping those struggling it's not just a job to those that work there it's a vocation which is very rare.  
I hope that i can bring some hope to just one person's life. The staff here really do a care and it seems will go over and beyond to support you! If you need support it's right here. Well done CGL.

author: Yellow river
title: Poor manner in answering the phone
body:
This week I called Monklands University Hospital.  
The switchboard operator had a very poor manner on answering the call. Perhaps they should be retrained in telephone manner. This lets the entire hospital down!

title: Disgraceful Manner
body: Attended walk-in centre on the morning of 1/8 for a blood test. This is the first time I've attended since the Coronavirus so I was unsure what the procedure would be. The only instruction I was given when I made the appointment was that I was asked to wear a mask, which I did. As I entered the centre, I noticed a table just inside the entrance and the passageway was partly roped off, but had sufficient room for people to pass. I paused to look for instructions, there were none, so I walked in and headed for reception. I was greeted by a very bad tempered woman bellowing out "whoa, whoa, whoa, you can't just walk in like that" and ushered me back to the table, asked whether I had any virus symptoms and took my temperature. As all was OK, I was allowed to approach reception. No apology for the very brusque manner. I have to say that I'm usually treated very well at the centre, the lady on reception and the nurse that treated me were lovely, but the way I was spoken to when I arrived was unacceptable. Fully appreciate the need to keep patients safe, which is why I paused to read any instructions, but this sort of attitude doesn't help anybody. Please review signage and staff training.

title: Excellent urgent treatment centre consult
body:
Excellent telephone consult with trainee ENP, who was quick, thorough and reassuring when reviewing our 2 year old daughter. 
Easy telephone consult, image upload and follow up review. I’m a Paeds ANP & needed a second opinion in Mummy mode; this service was fantastic & we’re very happy with the conservative approach suggested.

title: Good Care
body:
I had THR on 15/7/20 The procedure went smoothly. The surgeons and staff all very kind and encouraging. Two curtain girls went above and beyond helping me with emotions as well as pain. 
Lack of information regarding home care and follow up would have been helpful. Dos and Donts not apparent either. 
Generally great food and help. Felt PT bit rushed. 
.

title: NHS at it's very best
body:
After a long wait, I was admitted in July to the surgical unit for a hip replacement, and then looked after on the Frensham Ward before being discharged after just one night in hospital. All the staff I came into contact with were wonderful and all went out of their way to make my stay as comfortable as possible and help me recover quickly from the operation.  I observed staff helping other patients all the time, often under very difficult circumstances.
The safety measures in place for coronavirus seemed excellent and I observed all the staff complying with the strict precautions 100%. It made me feel very safe indeed. I watched the cleaners on the ward. So thorough and careful. My new hip is now 2 weeks old and I feel the operation has been a complete success. The significant pain I had endured for a year has gone. Thank you!

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Practice
body:
My doctor is extremely helpful and supportive he has got me through a difficult diagnosis and continues to support me through  it.
All the staff are helpful and polite.
Would highly recommend this practice.

title: Unwieldy administration
body: Both my wife and I have found the means of making appointments to see anyone in this practice unwieldy, not to say obstructive, both pre-Covid and more recently. We would be surprised if other patients do not feel the same, and would suggest that Alnwick Medical Group pays some urgent attention to streamlining their systems.

title: Telephone Staff
body: When I called to say I couldn’t feel my baby moving a lady answered and she was so rude in the way they talk to you as if it’s not important to them and it’s whatever. I understand the job is hard but this shouldn’t be the way I should be being spoken too when I am worried about my baby. The staff at the desk was nice and respectful but it’s like they want you in and out as soon as possible. I then called again and she was even more rude. I was trying to explain to her but the attitude was so wrong. I really don’t recommend making this place your trusted place they do not care.

title: Long wait but worth waiting for...
body:
I feel very fortunate to have been given the opportunity to work with my therapist. I felt held, heard and understood which allowed for a genuine counsellor/client relationship built on mutual trust and respect.  We developed a great connection which helped me to feel safe enough to explore my issues, face my anxieties and work through them whilst feeling safe and supported. My therapist was quite stern at times which was always in my best interests and still done with great patience, kindness and empathy. I will always be grateful for this as it encouraged me to keep going even through my darkest moments when I felt like running away. I can see now that with her support I found the strength to really face my demons and at times it was an incredible challenge but through hard work and a deeper understanding of myself and my issues it was well worth the effort as it has led to a much calmer place in my mind and body...I feel stronger and much more at ease... Guess you really do reap what you sow! 
The start of each session involved me being given choices plus the opportunity to add ideas on how the sessions may go, this was good as it created a sense of balance, equalness between my therapist  and I, plus I never once felt I was being forced to do anything against my wish. Homework was given which was great as it encouraged me to keep working on myself between sessions.
These 12 weeks have led me to a place where I can finally see a brighter future.  I'm under no illusion that all is completely perfect in my life now, there is still work to be done, however the path ahead is clearer as I've learned how to self soothe rather than rely on others for reassurance when I'm feeling anxious, therefore I'm seeing new perspectives when things feel tough like there's no way out... because there always is. Also, I feel it is very important to realize that when therapy ends the work should not. I'm still using all the exercises practiced, worksheets given, and notes taken whenever I feel necessary.  Some of the tools I've been given are now part of my daily regime and really help me to ditch not so helpful habits and introduce new and healthier ones... the beauty of self awareness and acceptance!
I have much and gratitude respect towards NHS Talking Therapies and to my wonderful therapist Ilknur. Thank you so much for your help support.

title: Terrible experience, again
body:
After a previous bad birth experience, I asked for an elective csection. After multiple meetings and calls, I was talked into booking in not be induced using a specific method to try and make the experience more controlled.
When I arrived for the said induction method, after being at the hospital for 4 hours they told me they couldn't do it because my cervix wasn't 'favourable', was then offered a pessary. This caused hyper stimulation and was taken. I then waited 8 hours for a Dr to attend to me who explained they wouldn't do anything else because they were so busy.
When I questioned the use of the first method, they said it was medically unlikely it would work but this was not true as I had heard them all outside at reception speaking about how they are only allowed to do two a day. So I spent two days waiting for something I was booked in for but didn't have done because they had over booked.
When I questioned the Dr about it, she apologises that I wasn't told the truth and suggested I come back next week to be "assessed".

Terrible second service from the F11 ward at the hospital and considering travelling an hour away to have my baby because of the lack of care or consideration for patients.

title: Life saving
body: My husband had his ICD box changed last Thursday and I cannot thank the whole team enough. He had an ICD originally implanted in 2010 and this was his second upgrade and yet again they saved his life. Thank you all so much. Brilliant team.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fantastic and amazing nurses
body: The nurses on duty on sat 1st Aug 2020 in A and E were rushed off their feet but when it was my turn were lovely kind fun and made me smile. NHS nurses you are the best!!!

author: Respected patient
title: Thank you for your kindness, empathy and care
body:
I was in ward 27 for 5 long weeks with a blood pressure problem and was generally unwell. It was during lockdown so I had no visitors for the first four weeks.  
I was extremely well looked after by every single staff member I had the pleasure to meet under very difficult circumstances. I would never have got through this without their kindness, from Karen the domestic who very kindly brought me in some surprise chocolate, to Jodi the student nurse who popped in to fix my pillows to try and make me more comfortable.  
Every single one (I wish I could name you all) of them including the Drs, nurses (all shifts), porters, I would love to name you all but I hope you all know how much I appreciated all you did for me.  
I would also like to say a huge thank you to every single one of the students who came into work early during COVID-19 I am so proud of you all you are simply a credit to the NHS and I will never forget the way I was treated with dignity, compassion, patience and kindness from every single person in ward 27 who looked after me.  
Even when I passed out in the shower you covered me up, maintained my dignity by covering me up, such kindness always came naturally to you all. I have been in hospital before but never ever have I been treated with such kindness and empathy.  
I’m still unwell but happy to be home with my lovely hubby who is looking after me, I thank you all from the bottom of my heart for all you are and all you do, I am proud of you all!  
Keep up the good work, I saw first hand how horrible you get treated by some extremely disrespectful patients, just keep rising above it. I take my hat off to you all and remember it’s those little things that mean a lot. I hope you are all truly proud of the people you are because you ALL truly should be!

title: Great Service
body: I recently attended the eye clinic for a field vision test only to arrive and be told the clinic was closed but the staff had a discussion and the test went ahead, Thank You to all the staff but it is nothing less than I have come to expect from the staff at S.G.H

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Wonderful service
body:
Thanks to the wonderful team from the very start to the very end who took such great care of my 5 year old daughter when she was admitted with breathing difficulties. It’s so humbling to put a loved ones life in the hands of complete strangers and watch them so tenderly and proficiently do all they can to help them. What a gift you all ❤️
She is now fast asleep at home recovering!

title: Excellent place
body: my husband was a patient on brookview ward  for3 months from may 4 until july 30. throughout this time I was kept up to date with events .Nothing was ever an issue for the staff  & despite my husbands case being very challenging at times I was always kept fully informed of progress. the staff always came accross as competent polite and professional. I always had confidence in them .I never worried about contacting them .I always felt reassured by them & therefore knew that my husband was in safe hands. they really are an excellent team.

title: The best
body: I was in kings lynn hospital in may and july not june as previously stated and spent most of my time in west raynam ward and terrington ward these doctors and nurses and all the other staff are the best anybody could hope for they do a superb job

readBy.name: The Queen Elizabeth Hospital Kings Lynn NHS Foundation Trust

title: Brilliant experience at a difficult time.
body: I want to say a massive thank you to all the lovely ladies who looked after me during my week in hospital. I was admitted to be induced early due to pre eclampsia, I spent time on a few of the different maternity wards and I only have good words to say about the people who looked after me. The midwives are angels who keep you going at a difficult time! It’s a shame I can’t mention the 3 stand out midwives who really made a difference to my week. I’ve now got my perfect, healthy happy boy who was born after a emergency C-section and I honestly feel without the support of the whole team in the maternity unit I couldn’t of got through it! Thank you everyone!!

title: superb
body: I was taken to papworth hospital from kings lynn hospital after i had a heart attack i had 2 stents fitted the ambulance crew the nurses on 3 south west ward porters and surgeon and doctors were all superb could not have hoped for anything better thankyou

title: Avoid at all costs
body:
Beginning of July I went to A&E in an ambulance as I was in af. I was triaged, told I was in af which I knew as this was the 3rd episode. I was then sat in a day room and pointed in the direction of the tea and coffee machine. Several hours later I was told to ‘go home and live with it’. A friend picked me up. I tried to walk up stairs when I got in and passed out. My wife took me to the northern general hospital at Sheffield they sorted everything out and put a comprehensive prevention plan in place. 
I have again been to DRI A&E twice this week with excruciating back and leg pain caused by a prolapsed disk. This again was in an ambulance as I am unable to walk due to the pain. On the first occasion I was given a little pain relief, same as I have at home that doesn’t work. I was asked to stand for 15 seconds this was horrendously painful I was then left alone, I couldn’t get back on the bed so I lay on the floor. I was sent home still in screaming agony being told they couldn’t do anything. I ended up back in A&E less than 48 hours later with the same, but now worse, pain, I was prescribed different pain medication and sent home still screaming in agony.  I am at present totally incapacitated with this pain. 
Please seriously consider other options when planing your health care!

title: Amazing dental staff
body: Went in due to a dental abscess where they told me I needed an extraction. and after explaining how terrified I was, the dentist and nurses were amazing. I went back in today for my tooth out and they were so understanding and reassuring . Talked me through it all aswell as telling me I could tell him to stop talking if it got too much 😂 genuinely wish I could have them as my permanent dentist.

readBy.name: Staffordshire and Stoke on Trent Partnership NHS Trust

title: Great Practice
body:
2 visits recently - excellent service.
Problems dealt with efficently and appointments easily arranged.
COVID guidelines easily followed , all staff very helpful.

title: Good, responsive and engaged GPs
body: Most of the GPs are extremely good - they listen carefully, are empathetic and responsive. They answer questions and try to see you or speak with you on the phone as soon as humanly possible. The reception staff, however, are sometimes less helpful, especially on the telephone. They seem, at times, to act as a barrier or obstacle. They also ask intrusive questions and there is not enough privacy in the surgery at the reception desk to feel comfortable answering such questions.

title: Helpful Staff
body: I visited the A&E department yesterday between 2:30pm and 8pm. From the moment I got there, the staff were extremely helpful and friendly. From the ambulance staff on site to the nurses, doctors and security officers. I found any staff I came into contact with, very attentive to why I was there and readily available to help with any new symptoms that arose.

title: reasonable practice for during pandemic
body: It seems a very efficient practice however the prescription service may not be to everyone's taste or capabilities of as the dedicated phone line was withdrawn.

title: Great practice but....
body: Most doctors at this practice are great. Sympathetic, helpful and thorough. But there is the odd one who has a dismissive attitude where you feel they would be helpful if your situation was life threatening but they don’t seem that bothered about more minor ‘quality of life’ issues.

title: Awful service - not enough staff to deal with no…
body:
Like several other people on here - I have spent over an hour trying to get through on the phone & have also had no response to emails.

They say they have 20,000 patients. That will generate an awful lot of phone calls & admin work & it is that side of the business, rather than the clinical side, which is sadly lacking.

It does appear that the Practice, which used to be very good in the old building, is now putting profit before patient care.

title: Cant Help because we are useless
body:
Went to store because the glasses frame had broke due to a screw breaking, They could not help because they could not remove the screw, the frames they no longer keep, they wont order me another pair based upon my previous prescription, they want me to have another eyetest first, but they want me to book on line for 2 weeks time to get an eye test, Even after telling them I need glasses to work and pay the bills. No empathy. 
Good service would have been, lets fit you in sometime today as an emergency case and get you some new glasses for this week. 
I was not after anything for nothing. 
Instead they sent me away without the means to see my work and with a " we dont care attitude "  All to often with these big companies. Not a helpful branch and not helpful people.

title: Useless
body: Ringing on behalf of an elderly neighbour, who couldn't cope with the instructions to be connected, not surprised, we tried to ring on his behalf and got cut off after opting to talk with someone 5 times

title: Lumbar puncture
body: I visited Lincoln hospital today for a lumbar puncture, I was quite anxious about this as people I had spoken to said it was painful. However the two lovely ladies at the hospital explained the procedure well and put me at ease. The procedure was carried out with great care and expertise, making it a painless experience. Thank you ladies.

title: Patient for many years
body:
I have been a patient with this surgery for many years
After reading the replies to some of the reviews I have decided to do a review
When my wife states she would rather be ill than have to deal with the rude lady who now answers the phone 
Yes we know we are in the middle of covid
The government are telling people to still contact GP if they are unwell 
Not everyone has the capacity or technology to download apps to speak to a GP
My worry is some serious illnesses are going to be ignored during this time as people are reluctant to deal with the non qualified rudeness you are met with when calling the surgery
The replies to the reviews state our reception staff when it’s clear everyone is talking about one person 
The Doctor is very good Shame she isn’t seeing these reviews

title: Excellent
body:
Thankyou to all who are providing an excellent service at a very difficult time. To those on reception, the young lady who carried out the vision tests and the Consultant who dealt with my assessment.
Your expertise and professionalism enabled me to feel relaxed and confident during what could have been a stressful experience. Thankyou.

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Ward F6 TEAM ARE OUT OF THIS WIRD
body: What a well-organized team of Doctors and nurses Ward 6, a great Ward, nothing is to much trouble any time you ask I must point out all other Wards I have been in are great, but this most recent one deserves a special thank you from myself, A credit to the NHS

title: Normally great but ...
body: I have always used Heartlands and never had a bad experience there until today. With a raging fever I got myself into a&e feeling very faint and unwell. I had my assessment and at the end was told to go and sit back in the waiting area. I politely asked if I could possibly have somewhere to lay my head as I felt so faint I was concerned about sitting up in the chair. In a full ward of people a locum nurse was exceedingly rude and told me people come to a&e for illness, not to go to sleep. I was absolutely shocked at the attitude as they were implying I had come to a&e for a lie down... funny the advice when you have a fever is to rest in bed but apparently its OK to sit on a metal chair for the 8 hour waiting time i was given. I was humiliated and made to feel like a time waster which I certainly am not. I complained to the reception staff and they were great about it and had another nurse come to speak to me. I totally understand it is a stressful time at the moment but there is no need to speak to patients like that and I was extremely upset. The permanent staff who worked there couldn't have been nicer but maybe it would be worth investigating the bedside manner of some of their locum staff...

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Much improvement
body: I have been deeling with the doctor over the last couple of months due to an ongoing issue. Today Friday I have spoke to a wonderful receptionist who made sure I had enough time to speak with the doctor and actually took the time to listen to me and put me right at ease. And she was right caring and patient with me. Over the last couple of weeks there has been a real improvement from the reception staff although there is still a couple who could do with a bit of work! In these hard and scary times it is so comforting to speak with someone who seems to care and understand our worries. As always the doctor is really good and understanding too.

title: Great service
body: I attended the the MIU clinic today with a severe ear infection, I was seen promptly by an extremely polite nurse, who assisted me in getting the right the help. I was in & out in a hour with a dose of antibiotics, cannot fault the service or care. Thank you : )!

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: NO LONGER PROVIDING CREDIBLE SERVICE
body: A surgery that doesn't answer its telephones, can provide no appointments, fails to keep its promises of "ring backs" and employs unhelpful receptionists has lost it focus on why a Doctor's surgery exists. A surgery is there to help and support people who are ill, not make their situation worse. This surgery is becoming of no use and is the architect of its own downfall by not understanding what its objectives are. Supporting people who need help isn't within its objectives.

title: Wonderful staff, awful design
body: I visited A&E with my daughter on 1st August, following a fall from her horse, whilst the staff are welcoming , helpful it is clear from the moment one arrives the dept is simply not able to cope. We were advised their was a minimum of a 6 hour wait, the waiting are was cramped and clearly the idea of social distancing was not feasible due to the numbers waiting for attention- it struck me as odd our horse had the attention of a trained equine medical professional within an hour of the incident, my daughter faced a 6 hour wait for the same level of attention. This is not a criticism of the staff who do an excellent job in clearly very  difficult Circumstances , this is meant As a wake up call for the hospital managers- take a long hard look at the design of the dept, redesign the area to give the staff and patients the best possible option your current environment is not fit for purpose.

title: Fantastic Clinic
body: Within 3 weeks of being sent to Spa Medica by my optician I had my first procedure which , to date, has  passed all my  expectation An unbelievable result. From Reception to leaving everything was perfectly executed.

title: Urgent Care
body: I had to take my 6 year old daughter today as she had an ear infection and needed antibiotics.  We both had our temperature taken at the door by the nurse (my daughter had a fever so we were put in a separate room) and was seen very quickly by a really lovely doctor who put my daughter at ease whilst he was looking in her ears.  We have been here a few times and sometimes the wait can be a bit long - it can get very busy as people normally use this service when no GP appointments are available - but I always find everyone to be very professional and friendly and I am very grateful to have this service so close to home. - Thank you.

title: Extremely grateful
body:
My GP has swiftly dealt with my early stage Cancer diagnosis. 
I have been lucky enough to fight off Cancer during Covid-19 times, my experience has been challenging for myself and my family, but I can honestly say that I have had the best possible care. 
Thank you very much.

author: jakethesnake
title: Hurting my leg and getting a plaster
body:
I hurt my leg on the bouncy trampoline at Mabie farm park and my dad had to take me to a&e.  
I got an xray and my mum got a teliphone call the next day to say that i had to go and get a plaster on it. The nurses and doctor a&e were very nice to me they tried to get me a boot but couldnt find one small enough.  
When i went the next day to get my plaster on the nurses were all very nice and spoke to me about my ankle and what would happen. A lovely physiotherapist also came to see me and spoke to my mum about hiring a wheelchair as we were going to Whitby for a few days on holiday.  
I went back today and seen Graeme and he cut the cast off for me. i am very happy. Andy was there both times. We like the same football team. Graeme was funny and made jokes.  
Thank you all for looking after me so well. I cant wait to go on my bike, hoverboard and play football again.  
(aged 8)

author: Hip Man
title: Wonderful care for hip replacement
body:
I had been in significant pain for 9 months waiting for a hip replacement. And then my surgery was postponed for at least 3 months because of coronavirus. It was quite depressing. But I decided to keep fit. Thanks to Joe Wickes!  
And finally got admitted to the Royal Surrey Hospital in mid-July under the care of Mr Rosson. It was exactly one year since first asking my GP to help me.  
After surgery, I was looked after on the Frensham Ward under the care of James, the Ward Nurse. All the staff I came into contact with were wonderful and all went out of their way to help me. I observed staff helping others time and time again, often under very difficult circumstances.  
The cleaners were so careful. It was very impressive watching them at work. The safety measures in place, because of coronavirus were excellent and all the staff followed these measures 100%. It made me feel very safe indeed.  
I was home after just one night in hospital and I cannot ever thank the Royal Surrey Hospital and its staff enough. Thank you!

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Trace22
title: Inpatient stay on AMSS
body:
I was seen in A & E Pilgrim first and cannot fault their care, really felt looked after and was promptly seen by a doctor and then admitted onto the ward.  
The care I received on AMSS was exceptional, all staff from nurses, health care, doctors, housekeeping and the ward clerks were very caring, professional and nothing was too much trouble. It was a very scary time, and they were all reassuring and I received the best care. Such a lovely ward, a credit to the NHS.  
I must also mention the lovely staff in the MRI department. I was very nervous due to suffering from claustrophobia. One of the ladies very kindly supported me throughout the process. I would not have got through it without her. I am very grateful for her care and compassion.

author: Jq
title: Minor injuries, New Vic, Glasgow
body:
I would like to thank John from minor injuries for taking such good care of my little girl when she attended for a fractured wrist. The whole experience from the staff on the front door to radiography team to nursing staff was phenomenal.  
All covid checks were carried out in a friendly and non-threatening manner so my 7 year old felt completely at ease. The staff were friendly and welcoming with a high level of clinical skills.  
We are so lucky to have such an amazing service, thank you from us all.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Toenail removal
body:
on way to holidays  in Newquay stubbed my toe, complete nail nearly off, visited A & E.. Excellent service, helpful staff Your hospital is a credit to NHS
Thank you

readBy.name: The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: When life gives you lemons...
body:
Do not stand at my grave and weep,
I am not there, I do not sleep. 

I am a thousand winds that blow.
I am the diamond glint on snow.
I am the sunlight on ripened grain.
I am the gentle autumn rain. 

When you wake in the morning hush,
I am the swift, uplifting rush
Of quiet birds in circling flight.
I am the soft starlight at night. 

Do not stand at my grave and weep.
I am not there, I do not sleep.
Do not stand at my grave and cry.
I am not there, I did not die.

title: Fantastic NHS. We love you
body: Went in for my cataract surgery as scheduled on time. I was treated so well. All the staff were wonderful. Everywhere was sparklingly clean and I felt safe and secure.The surgeon explained the procedure to me and reassured me. Operation was painless and only took a few minutes.

title: Excellent Service
body:
Was very weary of attending due to Covid. However could not fault the staff and treatment/diagnosis given. Total of 3.5 hours from walking in to walking out, X Ray, bloods, diagnosis and medication all done, along with appropriate advice given. 
It’s certainly improved since I last visited some 5+ years ago.

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Receptionist from hell!
body: I have been a patient at this surgery for a long time and it has had its ups and downs during my time with them, but during the last year or so it has dramatically changed for the worst. I am talking about the receptionists. There are a couple of them that unfortunately they have not the gift of “Customer Service”, they are rude from the moment they answer the phone, they make it very clear they don’t have any intention to help you, any intention to listen, cannot be bothered and have no manners whatsoever, they make it very clear they don’t want to be there and very clear that they hate this job..So you find yourself having to be extra careful on the tone you use when talking to them, on what you say to them, trying to be extra polite so that they may be just about ‘ok’ with you...Even before you speak they already have that “Passive Aggressive” attitude on the phone, making you feel you are a monster calling and they have to be nasty to you even before the conversation starts. My recent call at the surgery again wasn’t pleasant, considering that with this Covid situation we have to adapt to a new-way of living I asked if possible to give me an indication on when the Dr would call me, as I have to fit this call in between my daily routine meetings and other appointments. At first they said the call was booked for today at anytime, when I asked to be a bit more specific they were very annoyed and rudely said that they couldn’t give a time and it could be any time today, I then tried to explain my other commitments and appointments of the day and asked to leave a note to the Dr to try to avoid calling me during that time, I was then told that I was booked for the morning slot! So a minute earlier she couldn’t give me a time slot and suddenly I had a morning slot appointment?!? The thing that shocked me the most though is that while at the surgery waiting to be called in I overheard them making comments about patients, mostly calling them names and swearing at them after hanging up the phone, once after they hang up a call loudly they said the “F” words! The only way I can describe them (a couple of them only) is very unsympathetic, unhelpful, disrespectful, rude, bully with no manners and respect what so ever! They really needs to start from scratch...go back to basics or go home and leave space to new staff who seems to be thousands times better!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: MrsRMB
title: Sick Note/Fit Note - Post Operative Cancer Surgery
body:
My husband had part of his kidney removed at Castle Hill Hospital in Hull. He had a cancerous growth on his left kidney via keyhole surgery.  
The consultant advised it would be 4-6 week recovery time.  
He was discharged from the ward at the end of June with a sick note for 2 weeks. He was advised that his GP, West Common Lane Teaching Practice, would extend the sick note for the duration of his recovery.  
His sick note expired yesterday, and the GP will not issue another one, they state it is not their responsibility. They have referred me back to Castle Hill who state their policy is for 2 weeks sick note and sent me back to the GP.  
I have been back and forth for 3 days and neither will issue a sick note.  
So, based on this, is my husband required to return to work? He can't drive, he can barely climb the stairs, he is injecting blood thinners for another 2 weeks and still in compression stockings.  
He is not fit for work, yet I cannot get either party to issue a new sick note.  
For someone with cancer, who needs a peaceful and stress free recovery, you would think they might care the impact this red tape is having on the well being of a patient. Where is the duty of care?

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Stagbury1
title: Collapsed alone at home
body:
I collapsed at home early one Sunday at the beginning of July, broke out in a sweat and then chills, massive headache and not much recollection of what happened. I managed to contact my daughter , who rang 111 and after two phone calls an ambulance arrived within five minutes and I was taken off to A&E in Croydon University Hospital.  
My experience was excellent from the first calls to finally saying Goodbye at 10 pm at night. Should add no food or water were offered and by then I had been without for over eight hours or longer. During that time I was put on a drip, had loads of tests and generally looked after so well. Everyone without exception was so kind and caring. I felt safe.  
I was told to report to my surgery Parkside, during the week and also told that I must isolate until the covid test result came through. This I duly did and I presented myself at the practice for the requested blood test only to find they knew nothing of my admittance to A&E or what they found.  
I had been told that my sodium levels were very low, but the A&E doctors did not want to alter my medication anymore and in fact referred me back to my surgery.  
I found it strange that there was no communication in the ten days that had elapsed. I am a fairly "with it "86 year old retired nhs worker and don't worry unnecessarily.  
Could you please clarify this for me.  
I wonder how many older folk are left in the same position. I was not given a letter or any paperwork to present to my doctor.  
Is communication by email only and should not the practice have had some notification after ten days?

author: nitra
title: Glodwich Medical Centre
body:
I attended Glodwick for an ultra-sound in the Medicare Dept. On my arrival I went to reception and even with the screens in place the reception staff were not wearing masks, (I found this quite shocking especially with Oldham currently under the spotlight for a lockdown).  
I was called in for my appointment and was greeted by one gentleman wearing his mask whereas the other gentleman did not!  
I then entered the sonography room and the lady in there was wearing her mask yet the sonographer was, BUT not correctly. They had the mask over their mouth but their nose was clearly visible. I did make a comment about how people, in general, are not wearing masks correctly... he did not pick up on my comment!  
When I left my appointment I headed straight to the toilet, there weren't any sanitising stations and I was quite shocked, to be honest. I felt I needed to report my concerns about the sonographer to the reception but their attitude was not exactly proactive, instead, they directed me to another person who was unavailable.  
When leaving I immediately went to use the hand pump on the wall but unfortunately, the unit was empty and I was unable to sanitise.  
Given that we are in a global pandemic, health care is on the front line, and also under a HUGE microscope. My nerves were already on edge with my appointment being in Oldham and the attitude of the Glodwick staff were in my opinion not good enough.  
The NHS is meant to be setting an example, and for the most part, they are doing amazing work. Why is Oldham failing on this front?

author: Bladesman
title: Not getting help when wife is seriously ill
body:
My wife has a crisis took 4 days to come and see her.  
I rang on Friday only to be told we'll get back to you. It took 4 hours to ring me at 5 o’clock as they finish to be told to ring out of hours. The advice from out of hours was "tell her to have a cup of tea and calm down".  
At this stage she was manic. She was cleaning through the night. Rung again only to told "wear some ear muffs so you don’t hear her."  
Got some help Monday, only after ringing my GP. They come out and said she's very poorly, it’s the worse they seen her. I explain this to them Friday. So I had to cope from Friday till Monday with no help.  
This has been happening for the last 4 years. I'm not in full health myself. They think I’m making it up, but they see her now and again I live with her 24/7. What a shambles! Rant over.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: DA2020123
title: Very disappointed by treatment and aftercare for foot injury
body:
I attended Forth Valley A&E a few weeks ago with a suspected broken foot. On arrival I was unable to weight bear and hopped from the door to the reception without assistance from staff. Once booked in I waited to be triaged. I asked the receptionist and a member of nursing staff on 2 separate occasions for any pain killers and was advised that I would get some once triaged.  
I was called in by a nurse who asked me what happened. The nurse noted down the details of the incident but failed to take any observations or ask about my pain score. My foot was deformed at the ankle, ice cold to touch and the capillary refill was over 4 seconds. None of this was assessed.  
I asked for pain relief and was given 2 paracetamol and sat in a small waiting area to go for an xray. The porter and xray technician were the only positive experience I had during my visit and both were polite, courteous and professional. I was taken back to the waiting area after my xray.  
My pain was worsening while sitting and I asked a junior doctor and a member of nursing staff for more pain killers. The doctor walked past the door and said they had asked someone to get it and it hopefully should be soon. I waited nearly an hour.  
Once a member of nursing staff brought me into the cubicle I was given 1 tablet of dihydrocodeine. This was ineffective.  
I then waited for the doctor for another half an hour. Once assessed, the doctor advised it was a hairline fracture and provided me with a moon boot and a leaflet, referring me to the online fracture clinic. The doctor advised that all I would need is regular paracetamol and ibuprofen, both of which had already proved ineffective. The doctor told me that I was to wear the moon boot for 2 days and after that I should be fine. 11 days since the injury I am still unable to wear anything other than the moon boot and I still have significant bruising and excruciating pain when sleeping or attempting to wear normal footwear.  
Yesterday I contacted the online fracture clinic as I had not heard from them and my pain was worsening and the nurse told me that I had not been referred.  
I gave my employers inaccurate time scales regarding my injury and I am now looking at extensive time off. Having spoken to other medical professionals I believe the treatment and diagnosis management I have received has been grossly below par.  
I am now hoping the online fracture clinic nurse I spoke to can put together an effective rehabilitation plan as my mobility is still incredibly limited and my pain still not under control.  
I am extremely disappointed by the service and treatment I received both on the day and afterwards, and I very much look forward to hearing from a member of hospital management.

author: Milster1968
title: Lack of communication and urgency in emergency department
body:
I went to a & e with an idea I may have a kidney infection, turns out it was a water infection, a gallstone and sciatica.  
Seemed extremely uncoordinated from the start and my overall opinion is that communication within the department and between staff is not where it needs to be. I booked in at just after 9pm didn't get out till 2am even tho the time wait was 1-2 hrs.  
Wasn't overly busy either, however I saw many more people come and go... there doesn't seem to be any sense of urgency anywhere, the main culprits being the drs themselves, shuffling along at a very steady rate.  
In all during my visit I would estimate my time actually having processes and treatment equated to roughly 30mins (10-15 solely having a ct scan), by 5hrs into my visit I complained and was informed they had forgot about me when actually I should already have been allowed home. I only did this as a woman did the same 10 mins before me and low and behold she was speedily sorted out.  
I volunteered in the Pilgrim in lockdown and had utmost regard for the staff. I worked hard and thorough and felt like I was part of a great team, however this visit made me feel very overlooked, undervalued and inconsequential. I wish I hadn't have bothered to be honest even though it was the right thing to do. Hope I never have to repeat the scenario.  
I will add that I was in work from 8am that morning, had nothing as such to eat and was extremely tired and drained. When I got in my car to go home I openly admit I sobbed all the way home, I felt so let down by the whole experience.

author: Larst55
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Very grateful to the team
body:
Struggling with my walking outdoors and have had quite a lot of falls, visited at home by the Community Therapy Team and assessed outside to see how i managed. Was able to trial two different types of outdoor walking frames and following a discussion with the person assessing decide which frame would work better for me.  
Very greatful to the team and glad i can contact again if needed.

title: Excellent practice
body:
I was talen care of after suffering a massive stroke. The nursing staff are A1 and totally dedicated to every patient. Their total attention and care to me whilst recovering from the stroke was 100%..

Thank you all so much...I will never forget my 10 weeks in your care.

Anthony Larkin.  Eastbourne.

title: Birth and Beyond - Online antenatal classes
body: Just completed the"Birth and Beyond" antenatal class (online due to Covid).  The course was very informative and the midwife running it was fantastic.  She was knowledgeable and engaging and the online format worked really well.  We were worried the 2.5 hour sessions would feel like a long time but they flew by!  Thanks so much to the maternity team for providing this support during a difficult time, we now feel so much more prepared for what is to come.

title: Hero’s
body: Spoke with Dentaline Chatham and they where brilliant helped me by giving my brilliant advice and when I called back to tell them I had swelling on my face they sent a prescription to the pharmacy, can’t thank them enough, 😊😊😊👍👍👍👏👏👏

title: Website
body: The web site is confusing when I was trying to book a consultation I ended up on LIVI which I thought was part of the practice. When I phoned and spoke to a receptionist she said the practice was nothing to do with LIVI. I feel this should be made clearer

title: Overflowing bins and empty sanitiser dispensers
body: I walked through the main hospital past the cafeteria and observed several overflowing bins with discarded masks on the floor. I tried several dispensers that were empty or didn’t work, one of which was at the entrance to the cafeteria

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: bad impression
body: I tried to register here and they told me I can't because covid. They said it was fine that I'm registered far away and to register when covid is over. I want to register close to where I live and need an appointment. NHS guidance says GP should still be registering patients during this time, so I don't know what they are playing at.

title: Polite staff
body: The staff at the practice are really respectful and accommodating. They do their best to go the extra mile to make sure that patients feel happy when they leave. I had urgent blood tests needed doing and i couldn't go to hospital. The doctor at the practice was able to see me and i had my blood test done here which was convenient. I wouldnt know what to do without this practice during the lockdown as i am a unwell person and i cant travel very far.

title: On line prescriptions
body: Just been told by person on reception that I could not order my prescription on line until the date it was due. How stupid is this when it takes a few days to process. My prescription dste for reordering is 5.8.20. Today 3.8.20. I was told I could only order on line on the due date!

title: APPAULING
body: Every time you call to make an appointment you are told fully booked. Call back tomorrow. Carry out the instructions and call next day and the same response. Tried to explain the problems and asked for call back to discuss this matter over the phone and still nobody available to do this.  Talk to a pharmacy and he states you need to see your GP.  What is it with some GP's.  Never had this issue at my old practice.

title: Goods Practice in need of moderniaation
body:
Generally excellent, but the online repeat prescription service is in direr need of modernisation. I hope the day when I can order and receive a prescription without the stress, and need to visit the surgery and a chemist, and the hours all this takes is not far away. Twyford is not a small hamlet in the back of beyond, it's on the main line between Reading an Maidenhead.
Kind Regards,

Paul Martin

title: New online booking process is fantastic!
body: I have used the new online triaging appointment process twice since March and I would just like to say I think this process is great!  As a working parent, attending a GP appointment isn't always a straight-forward process for me with work/ school etc.  I was able to contact the GP with my concerns and within a couple of hours I was sent a full response from the GP, along with blood forms and a link to booking an appointment at a local blood clinic.  My bloods were completed and 24 hours later the GP had contacted me again without any need to chase up and all this was done without me needing to take any time off work.  I must point out that I did not need to physically see a GP for this appointment, I just needed to discuss a non-urgent query.  I urge my fellow patients to be realistic about their needs - not every appointment needs to be completed face to face and therefore this process is an excellent way to contact the GP safely and long may it continue!!!

title: Thank you!
body: Sent an e-consult on Sunday evening. Monday morning received text that my treatment had been issued to my pharmacy (re-occurrence of a previous condition. Sent photo with e-consult so no need to see or talk to me). So easy. Thank you to all the staff for keeping the service running so smoothly in these troubled times.

title: Great Gp
body: When evere I give call Gp Doctor give me good and right tretment for any hetlh problem. And quick appoiment as well.

title: Electronic contact
body: Visiting the GP has always been a good experience but the new web site and way of interacting over the net is awful.  Nothing can replace talking, more so when the problem is not straight forward.  I have been so frustrated at being asked to entrer details on line. Having done so the reply was obscure and I still dont know what is happening. I just havent go an answer after days of trying and I still do not have my perscription. I am away from home and cant visit the surgery.  My daughter would collect perscription but it is not there. I have high blood pressure, it is getting higher!!!

title: Safe and well managed care home
body: I have been impressed with the way steps were taken to safeguard the residents and staff during the coronavirus pandemic. In the last few weeks mum and I have been able to visit my brother at Bay Trees by sitting outside the conservatory with him inside. He was pleased to see us and looked well. I thank all the staff doing a difficult job at the present time, keeping the residents entertained and engaged.

title: Long waits and inaccurate response
body: After being told I don't suffer from severe headaches after 4 years since diagnosis I've been on the phone for over 1hr 30mins trying to book a MRI. I completely understand the strains the hospital is currently under, but patients with long term health problems have been left with very little support. This has an immense impact on patients both mentally and physically. Please try and improve your services.

title: Wow
body: I was blown away by the speedy and thoughtful care I received during this hard time. Best experience with a GP I’ve had in London.

title: Not the best
body: Our sad had a, stroke in May, he has dementia too.  Obviously under covid rules we can't go in to see him so set up a  daily zoom.  Some nurses and hca are brilliant, some seem not to be bothered. With dad's dementia it's vital he sees people he knows. But the lack of communication sometimes is not good or helpful to anyone.  It's sad times.  And we understand that the staff are under so much pressure. But it's the little things that make such a difference.  But we are grateful to the hospital for their care of dad..

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

author: Christmas 098
title: Diadem medical practice
body:
I have been at diadem surgery since I was 6 months old. I am now 62. The Doctor at the surgery have no time to get to know the patient. I remember the 3 Drs who were in the practice. The practice was a house on Hopewell road and Barham Road The three Doctors would call in to see how the family were. after a illness they knew all the families by name My Dad was a fisherman and when he came home I would take the Doctors some fish they knew all the family and nothing was to much bother they always had the time. my brother in law was really ill.  
Now the new Doctors I don't even know what their names are. when my mum became ill I was constantly asking for a visit. In March I called the Doctor again asking for a visit. On the Sunday a nurse came to see mum from Longhill and could not do enough she went up and above to help us with our mum. On the Monday after diadem medical practice decided to send us a Doctor but by this time my mum was in a coma we received no care or advice about my mum from this surgery.  
she passed away 4 days later. She had worked hard all her life and deserved better. My Partner is very ill and no Doctor has been out to see him he was asked to come in and give Blood. he was told to ring for blood results in a week when he did the blood had never reached the lab, he then had to go back and do more blood test he has lost 3 stone in weight and still no Doctor visit only telephone consultation.  
I rang the Doctors again for a visit I got told to ring 111 when I did they told me to call my Doctor as my partner needed a visit we have finally got a appointment they say we should be carful as we could lose our NHS.  
I think with the service we are receiving it's hanging on by a thread . There is no care anymore Doctor say that they are under pressure but I feel that as they don't do home visits or basic things like talking bloods why do they not have more time to get to know their patients?

author: SWH
title: She really helped me settle
body:
We were in for the birth of our baby & also visited the ward during pregnancy for hyperemisis and have been back in post natal.  
We were made to feel relaxed, supported and cared for throughout. The team on the ward and also in labour suite were incredible.  
A special mention for Susie who was absolute fantastic & really helped me settle when staying over without my partner and helped with feeding. Taking time to come and speak to me & made everything feel very genuine and understanding with me.

author: Lizzie60
title: MY CATTARACT OPERATION
body: Had a great experience the staff really looked after me and made me feel at home as was a bit nervous but everything was great. Would like to thank Dr Stiles who did my procedure. I was in great hands and to Ashley the nurse who looked after me. Would highly recommend this procedure at the cataract unit Thanks again

author: Adopted Scot
title: I just feel very lucky to have entered the hospital when I did
body:
My overwhelming thought one night was to see the next morning. Felt worse, in spite of prescribed antibiotics and took the very lucky decision to visit A&E. Staggered into A&E with extreme breathing difficulties that were worsening by the hour and from that moment, received 150% care.  
After Covid19 test, CT scan and other explorations it was clear I was suffering blood clots on both lungs, technically pulmonary embolism. Given blood thinning injections and medicines, then transferred to a general ward for monitoring vital functions, the general attention was exemplary.  
I cannot offer higher praise to all the staff who dealt with my health, from my initial induction through A&E, porters, cleaning, catering, technical, nursing; everyone, co-operation, co-ordination, communication and teamwork. It would be unfair to mention all the names and can't remember them all anyway. Just suffice to say that, after three nights/four days I am discharged and very definitely on the mend.  
Always enjoying great health, this experience was a shock as one expects to be almost invulnerable. The condition had clearly been building since January when I first felt the symptoms that strangely almost disappeared until re-emerging to a greater extent in June.  
So I spent the best part of a week in hospital, my co-patients were great; probably suffering worse illnesses than me, I just feel very lucky to have entered the hospital when I did. The alternative did cross my mind several times over the last few weeks until the diagnosis on Tuesday afternoon.  
Like a certain political character I will always be grateful for our NHS

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Rejuvenated123
title: I felt the care was outstanding
body:
I was admitted for surgery. The surgery I received was more difficult than anticipated and I was in hospital for 2 weeks being supported by the team in Day Surgery.  
Megan, one of the staff nurses was with me when I came out of the anaesthetic and over my 2 week stay on the ward was always professional, with myself , other patients and her colleagues. I saw someone who was hard working, an important member of a well oiled team and very dedicated to all aspects of her role which she performed with ease and proficiency . Nothing was to much to ask for when I needed help particularly on the days I felt I was in a difficult place.  
I felt the care was outstanding from Megan and the wider team who are all an asset to Forth Valley Royal Hospital.

author: JTA
title: Exceptional Person Centred Care
body:
Our mum was diagnosed with endometrial cancer in September 2019. She had surgery in November and commenced radiotherapy in January 2020, completing this early March just prior to Covid-19 lockdown. Our mum sadly passed away in July in the Beatson.  
We wanted to highlight the exceptional care she had throughout her journey. The cancer pathway was faultless and timely with no delays. She received truly person centred care by her Consultants - Dr Hardie, Consultant Gynaecologist and Dr Graham, Consultant Clinical Oncologist. The approach and relationship they built with mum made her feel at ease, reassured and she trusted them which gave her such a positive outlook. Latterly Lisa, Deputy Charge Nurse Ward B5 at the Beatson showed great care and compassion towards our mum and particular thanks also to Maureen.  
Although we don't have our mum now, the care shown throughout her journey has given us and my dad great comfort. My sister and I are proud to work in the NHS.

readBy.name: University of Glasgow - School of Medicine, Dentistry and Nursing

title: If you are not dead - no one will help you out
body:
I have been there quite few times with ongoing symptoms - shortness of breath,chest pain,rib cage pain,fainting,feeling extremely tired.....etc
Every time i was told take paracetomol,ibuprofen or gaviscon
Asked for tests where i had only tests for myeloma and repeated test for UTI
Had to live in pain and fed up calling GP as no chance to get through so went to A&E
They did more tests,said you are ok,go back for follow up.to your GP anf keep taking paracetomol
The pain got worse went to my bones,joints,was still feeling extremely tired.
Rang my GP(managed to get through) and asked for CT scan or something to find out what is wrong with me
Got a CT scan done which came back normal but the pain.didnt go anywhere
It did continue to.raise - i cab barely walk now as it went to my knees,constantly bloated,using toilet only 1 -2 times a day for a wee.
Urine is always dark yellow or orange,comes out very small amounts
Rang GP - got answer drink more water!!!!
I do drink 3 -4 liters of water every day.cant take any more!!!!
Went to A&E in Watford, have been asked to go home and not to come here anymore as they did everything they could and as a.doctor said to me-" its not our problem,go back.to your GP.
Rude!!!
Went to A&E in Dunstable,they did some urine and blood tests and said i have some issues with my kidneys.Have to book app with mg GP
So long story short - no chance yo get through to GP,as no appointments available
Rang the other day our surgery and been.told straight away on a phone - "your CT scan came normal,you dont have a cancer so its not a priority"!!!!!!
Is only cancer is the only ilness???Will i only receive a treatment when i get cancer????
So im.stuck - laying in pain,having urine tract issues,can barely stand up from a bed as knee pain, having shortness of breath and rib pain but i dont have a CANCER  so im not on their priority list
What should do???
Any advice please!!!!?!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Gratefuldaughter15
title: Assisted conception and our pregnancy journey
body:
My husband and I began attending Glasgow Royal Infirmary last summer to begin the process of IVF. At each appointment we were treated with the upmost professionalism and kindness by every individual we met. What was really lovely for me was that at each stage staff would congratulate me on getting that far and share their excitement at how well we were doing. We felt so supported throughout our treatment.  
We were delighted to fall pregnant on our first cycle and attending for our first scan was such a lovely experience. The staff were as excited and pleased as we were. We cannot thank everyone at Glasgow ACS for giving us our beautiful daughter.  
Delighted as we were to be pregnant, being so during a pandemic is not without its challenges and the care I received from my community midwife Margaret at Llanark Health Centre was exemplary. She was so so kind and always took the time to make sure I could record baby’s heartbeat for my husband to hear, answered every daft question I had and genuinely was a god send throughout my pregnancy.  
Finally we would like to thank everyone at the maternity unit at Wishaw University Hospital for delivering our baby safely and taking such excellent care of us.  
Our delivery and subsequent care was amazing especially given it didn’t quite all go to plan. Each and every member of staff was professional kind and a joy to be looked after by. Special mention to the final year midwifery students Ashleigh, Kirsty, Karen and Lauren. You ladies are born for your profession and we wish you all the best with your new careers.  
Without the NHS we would not have our beautiful daughter and we cannot thank you enough for this amazing gift and for taking such good care of us as a family each and every step of the way.

author: Clumsy Gardener
title: Kind, humorous and professional
body: I was treated there in August for a deep cut to my ankle and just wanted to say that all of the staff are excellent from start to finish from the porter to the Doctors! They were kind humorous and professional couldn't be happier!

author: GratefulOne
title: I have my eyesight back, and for that I am very, very grateful,
body:
I have been a Type 1 diabetic for close to 40 years. Over this time I have been acutely aware of the many complications that could/would affect me.  
It was during one of the routine eye checks (retinopathy) that abnormal blood vessel growth was detected, for which laser treatment was required. I also had cataracts developing.  
After 3 sessions of laser treatment, the blood vessel situation has been resolved, but the cataracts continued to develop, quite quickly, to the point of in a 12 month period, normal activities (reading, driving....) became nigh on impossible.  
The first cataract was removed in January this year, The second, last week.  
At each & every stage of the process; at each & every appointment, staff, whether they be receptionists, nursing or the doctors/consultants made the journey a smooth and uneventful one, With caring, attention to detail & knowledge, they put me at ease. They gave me the necessary information & assurances I needed.  
They said to me "we are just doing our job".  
To me, for every one of them, it is quite clearly much more than 'just' a job that they do.  
I have no complaints.  
What I do have is my eyesight back, and for that I am very, very grateful,  
Thank you all.

author: Emeraldy
title: She felt like she was his only patient
body: Owen Denham was described by Joyce as the kindest, most   patient and polite man who helped her cope with her stoma needs. He respected her dignity and she felt like she was his only patient such was his exceptional care.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Rude receptionists and slow service from doctors
body: I'll explain my first point of rude receptionists first. The receptionists have no mannerisms at all and make me wonder what qualifications they have and how they even got their job in the first place. Speaking to them on the phone recently, they tried giving me medical advice that would require a doctors level of knowledge! Also they have no sense of confidentiality easily giving away medication details over the phone when asked with no confirmation of identity. Calling in the morning is ridiculous for an appointment; I've once had to call over a hundred times to even get through to make an appointment. Now in terms of my second point, I have had chronic knee pain for months and I went for three appointments at this medical centre to find out the cause of the pain and for some treatment. The first appointment resulted in me getting a print out of exercises which I could try at home, which is an understandable conservative approach to the pain. Then the last time I went, I was told by a doctor I would be given a physiotherapy appointment at the hospital. I waited for months and never received a letter for an appointment. So, I registered at a GP surgery in Birmingham close to my university and booked a same-day appointment easily for my knee pain. The doctor there did a full knee examination of me on the bed testing every ligament whilst the doctors at Derby Family Medical Centre did partial knee examinations on me whilst I was sat on a chair. Then my Birmingham doctor gave me my diagnosis in the same appointment, and booked an appointment right in front of me for a physiotherapy appointment and allowed me to choose the date and time. Now can you see the difference in care between these two places? The Derby surgery failed to give me a diagnosis and support over many appointments and months. Whilst the Birmingham surgery managed to give me my diagnosis and treatment plan within the same 10 minute appointment. My point here is that one of these places still has the paternalistic approach to a doctor-patient appointment whilst the other place has the patient-centred approach which is most definitely what is needed in this day and age. The majority of the patients at Derby Family Medical Centre may not have English as their first language so the paternalistic approach may seem appropriate but with my mother at this surgery, I can confirm that she would much rather be involved with decisions regarding her medical plan and not be denied access to any medical decisions made about herself.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
